conclusion: To compare internal energy at state a and c, analyze the P-V diagram for an ideal gas.
Adiabatic processes involve no heat exchange; isochoric processes occur at constant volume.
Internal energy of an ideal gas depends only on temperature: U = (3/2)nRT for a monatomic gas.
From a to b: Isochoric process, no work done, change in internal energy due to heat transfer.
From b to c: Adiabatic process, no heat transfer, work done changes internal energy.
From c to d: Isochoric process at different volume, no work done, change in internal energy due to heat transfer.
From d to a: Adiabatic process, no heat transfer, work done changes internal energy.
For states on the same adiabatic curve, internal energy depends on volume.
Adiabatic curves represent constant entropy processes; higher curve means higher internal energy and temperature.
State a is on a lower adiabatic curve than state c; state c has higher internal energy.
Conclusion: Internal energy at state c is greater than at state a.
